docs.lead_paragraph: Every working adult has known one -- a boss who loves making subordinates squirm, whose moods radiate through the office, sending workers scurrying for cover, whose very voice causes stomach muscles to clench and pulses to quicken. It is not long before dissatisfaction spreads, rivalries simmer, sycophants flourish. Normally self-confident professionals can dissolve into quivering bundles of neuroses.

headline.main: Fear in the Workplace: The Bullying Boss

docs.abstract: Researchers, who might traditionally study child's bullying behavior on playground, are beginning to study bullies of adult workplace; Dr Gary Namie, Workplace Bullying and Trauma Institute director, holds that adult bullies will pick on weak or strong subordinates without discrimination, but are more likely to bully women rather than men; research shows that managers tend to bully because they enjoy flexing their power, not for business reasons; Dr Harvey A Hornstein book Brutal Bosses and Their Prey contends that although bullying creates disharmonious work environment, bullied workers do not produce less or more than their usual output; ways bullying bosses affect workplace discussed; types of bullies described; drawings (L)
docs.snippet: Every working adult has known one -- a boss who loves making subordinates squirm, whose moods radiate through the office, sending workers scurrying for cover, whose very voice causes stomach muscles to clench and pulses to quicken.    It is not long...

docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Too much sleep is bad for you. THE FACTS -- Most Americans relish the thought of sleeping late, and experts have traditionally recommended eight hours of rest each night. But a 2002 study found that getting more than seven hours of sleep each night was associated with a shorter life span. Several studies since then, including one this year by researchers at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, also found a link.
docs.abstract: Recent study on sleep shows that mortality rates increase when individuals average more than seven hours of sleep per night; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: THE CLAIM -- Too much sleep is bad for you.    THE FACTS -- Most Americans relish the thought of sleeping late, and experts have traditionally recommended eight hours of rest each night. But a 2002 study found that getting more than seven hours of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Kenneth Kamler, 56, is a man with a double life. For much of the year, he labors as a Long Island-based microsurgeon, specializing in hand reconstruction and finger reattachment. In his other guise, Dr. Kamler is an eminent adventure physician, a staff doctor with scientific expeditions journeying to remote corners to investigate how crocodiles mate or how NASA's medical equipment works at high altitudes. He is a vice president of the prestigious Explorers Club in New York. As part of his second specialty, Dr. Kamler has been to Mount Everest six times and was on the mountain in 1996 when eight mountaineers died, a disaster chronicled in Jon Krakauer's book ''Into Thin Air.'' Dr. Kamler provided emergency treatment to the survivors.

headline.main: A CONVERSATION WITH/Kenneth Kamler; Bringing Them Back, Healthy, From the Ends of the Earth

docs.abstract: Interview with Kenneth Kamler, hand surgeon and eminent adventure physician, discusses how he became involved in various expeditions and preparations he makes prior to exotic trips; Kamler, who is vice pres of Explorers Club, New York, has been part of six Everest expeditions; his book Surviving the Extremes describes some of his journeys; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: If you cannot stop a snorer from snoring, how can you cut down on the noise? One way may be by inserting small plastic strips into the soft tissue at the top of the mouth, according to a study released yesterday. The study, published in The Archives of Otolaryngology, noted that snoring was a result of turbulent airflow through the throat that occurred when the airway was constricted during sleep.

headline.main: A Mute for the Roar of the Snorer

docs.abstract: University of Hong Kong researchers, who have inserted three plastic strips into palates of 12 snorers, have found that rigid palate appears to minimize vibrations and reduce noise from snorers; study is published in Archives of Otolaryngology; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The first time Jane Leffingwell was told that she had a precancerous lesion of the breast, she received the least aggressive treatment available: breast-conserving surgery, or lumpectomy. She was 46, and her lesion, called ductal carcinoma in situ, or D.C.I.S., was deemed low grade, with a low likelihood of recurring.

headline.main: A Debate on How to Treat Precancerous Breast Disease

docs.abstract: Diagnosis of ductal carcinoma in Situ, DCIS, has increased dramatically since routine use of mammography to test for breast cancer; doctors are not in agreement about how agressively to treat DCIS, which has 10-year mortality rate of around one percent; traditional treatment was with mastectomy and lymph node biopsies, but starting in 1999 there has been marked shift to less-agressive lumpectomy plus radiation treatment; Journal of the National Cancer Institute recently published review that suggests there is little difference in survival rates among different treatments, thereby advocating less invasive treatment; survival and reccurrence rates for DCIS discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Welcome to the world of anti-aging cosmetics, a vast and chaotic bazaar where hundreds of creams, lotions and gels vie for the dollars of 90 million Americans eager to turn back the clock. The competing claims in this marketplace have always been bewildering. Do antioxidants work better than alpha hydroxy acids to make skin smooth? Can lavender or aloe vera erase wrinkles?

headline.main: New Creams Smooth Wrinkles, but They're Not Botox

docs.abstract: Americans spent $1.15 billion on anti-aging cosmetics in 2002; dermatologists and plastic surgeons generally agree that over-the-counter skin care products can help reduce wrinkles, but do not suggest that creams match effectiveness of surgical procedures; new creams containing short-chain peptides, such as Regenerist and StriVectin, show increased collagen production; Food and Drug Administration regulates safety of cosmetics, but does not regulate effectiveness of anti-aging creams; Lab 21, which sells custom cream based on testing of customer's DNA, is one of newest concepts in anti-aging products; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Welcome to the world of anti-aging cosmetics, a vast and chaotic bazaar where hundreds of creams, lotions and gels vie for the dollars of 90 million Americans eager to turn back the clock.    The competing claims in this marketplace have always been...

docs.lead_paragraph: Treating elevated blood pressure within the eye can cut in half the risk of glaucoma for African-Americans, according to a new study. African-Americans face a far higher risk of blindness from the condition than whites do. The study, published last week in The Archives of Ophthalmology, drew on data from the extension of a clinical trial whose preliminary results were published in 2002.

headline.main: Weapons in the War on Glaucoma

docs.abstract: Dr Mae O Gordon, Washington University School of Medicine, St Louis, researcher, leads study on glaucoma; research, published in Archives of Ophthalmology, shows that reduction of elevated blood pressure within eye can cut in half risk of African-Americans developing glaucoma; glaucoma is leading cause of blindness among blacks in United States (S)
docs.snippet: Treating elevated blood pressure within the eye can cut in half the risk of glaucoma for African-Americans, according to a new study. African-Americans face a far higher risk of blindness from the condition than whites do.    The study, published...

docs.lead_paragraph: Acupuncture may have lasting benefits for neck pain, the authors of a new study say. The study found that people who received acupuncture had less pain three years later than people with similar pain who received a dummy treatment.
docs.abstract: University of Oslo, Norway, researchers conduct study on effectivenss of acupuncture on neck pain; research, published in journal Pain, finds that acupuncture has lasting benefits in reducing pain with those receiving treatment measuring 70 percent reduction in pain; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Acupuncture may have lasting benefits for neck pain, the authors of a new study say.    The study found that people who received acupuncture had less pain three years later than people with similar pain who received a dummy treatment.

docs.lead_paragraph: In 1931, a third-year Harvard medical student saw a cluster of small red dots on his forearm and knew without a shadow of a doubt that he would be dead within six months. In 1942, an obscure medical journal published the student's diary posthumously, for he did indeed die of the disease he had diagnosed in himself, subacute bacterial endocarditis, an infection of the heart valves that was uniformly fatal before the advent of antibiotics.

headline.main: Paying Homage to the Wisdom of Voices From Medicine's Past

docs.abstract: Abigail Zuger's Cases column supports preservation of historical medical information; holds that although medicine is ever-changing and new medical advances often provide clearer answers for doctors, much can be learned from history (M)
